data.text: Index
The Trust finances the purchase of many IT Assets and has a substantial inventory of equipment that is recorded in the IT asset database or Configuration Management Database' CMDB.

Such assets need to be allocated for maximum utilisation in terms of financial returns and informational benefit. To achieve this, the Trust is required to implement and notify staff of its and their obligations in respect of equipment that is allocated to them to undertake their job via this policy.
This policy defines the policy for procurement, registration, deployment, transfer, operation and disposal of IT assets purchased or leased by the Trust whilst on and off the premises.

The aim of this policy is to protect the organisation from financial loss with potential future loss or damage to assets and will also provide strong, reliable and robust procedures and processes to support Information Security and Information Governance to British/ISO, ITIL and other standards.

Information security is not only established with software authentication mechanisms and encryption but also in the location and usage of the devices themselves. This policy will cover all Information Technology Assets – hardware or software – since these have intrinsic value to the Trust and will be registered and monitored. Information security via a physical hardware asset is covered by this policy where, for example, it cannot be retrieved or has been lost.

This policy applies to employees, contractors, business consultants, temporaries, and other workers, including all personnel affiliated with third parties of Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.

This policy covers to all portable devices such as laptops, smartphones, mobile phones, netbooks etc. where it was supplied by Digital Services. The procurement of portable devices that circumvent Digital Services will be the responsibility of the department that obtained the device, any support from Digital Services will be on a best endeavours basis.
This document does not cover other Trust non-IT assets that will be covered by their respective policies.
The purpose of this policy is to inform all staff of the regarding:
The implementation/deployment planning of IT assets
Deployment (implementation in case of software) of acquired IT assets
Management and tracking of IT assets (location, keeper, status)
Define asset keepers restrictions/limitations of the use of IT assets
Required minimal security measures to be observed by the asset keeper
Audit and inventory tracking of IT assets
Control and reconciliation of IT assets
Disposal of IT assets and updating the IT asset register (the database)
Definitions and Terminology

table_items.text: This should be in reference to the individual Trust that the employee is employed by. Trusts refereed to include Mid Essex Hospital NHS Trust, Southend University Hospital NHS Foundation Trust, and Basildon and Thurrock University Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust.

Applications which are across a range of software platforms e.g. IOS, Windows, Android, Linux.
For the purposes of this document this term will relate to information technology hardware and software unless otherwise stated. Other Trust assets will be covered by their respective policies
Staff member given full responsibility for the use of the specified IT asset. The term is used to avoid confusion with Information Asset Owners (IAOs)and Administrators (IAAs) .

Configuration Management Database – an ITIL Service Management term. A configuration management database (CMDB) is a repository that holds the details on a collection of IT assets - referred to as configuration items (CI) - as well as descriptive relationships between such assets.
The Trust's Information Asset Register is a register of information assets, containing key information e.g. nature of the asset, what type of information the asset contains etc.
Preservation of confidentiality, integrity and availability of information. Authenticity, accountability, non-repudiation and reliability
Identified possible security breach of information security policy where safeguards have failed or previously unknown situation has occurred
A consumer orientated mobile device that maybe either the personal property of a member of staff, or Trust issued to meet a specific business need.

Person Identifiable Information / Person Identifiable Data / Personal Confidential Data. One or more pieces of information that relate to an individual, who can be identified from those pieces of information or identified by combining those pieces of information with other information that is likely to be available. The individuals concerned may be patients, staff, contractors or members of the public.
Any product of someone's intellect that has commercial value, especially copyrighted material, patents, and trademarks.

data.text: Roles & Responsibilities
Role & Responsibilities within the Trust (Committees)
4.1.1 Digital Services Governance Group – to review policies and recommend submission for group approval.
4.1.2 Information Governance Committee – to review any instances of non-compliance to stated policy.
4.1.3 Joint Document Management Group – to ratify policies.
Role & Responsibilities of Individuals within the Trust
4.2.1 Senior Information Risk Officer (SIRO) – Joint Executive Group (JEG) appointed Chief Information Officer responsible for ensuring:
Serious information risk management issues are brought to the Board for decision as required.
A lead or manager is in place to organise and enforce the Group's approach to information risk management.
Written advice is provided to the Accountable Officer and appropriate Trust Boards regarding the information risk management content of the annual report and Statement of Internal Control (SIC).
4.2.2 Caldicott Guardian – Board appointed Site Director for each Trust is responsible for:
Protecting the confidentiality of PCD processed by the Trust, ensuring that all sites satisfy the highest practical standards for handling PCD.
Acting as the “conscience” of the Trust, by actively supporting work to enable use and sharing of PCD where this is appropriate and advising on lawful and ethical solutions.
Championing confidentiality and information sharing requirements and issues at Board level and, where appropriate, at a range of levels within the Trust's overall governance framework.
4.2.3 Head of Digital Services, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for development and updating of Digital Services Policies.
4.2.4 Head of Information Governance, MSB Group
Operational responsibility for information governance.
4.2.5 Line Managers
Responsible for ensuring that staff are aware of this policy that they adhere to it and for managing issues which arise when staff fail to comply.
4.2.6 Trust Staff
Responsible for implementing and complying with the policy within the areas of their responsibility or control.
Policy Requirements
Overview and Types of Assets

5.1.1 IT  assets  include  physical  hardware,  infrastructure,  and  software  licencing  and provisioning to best serve the operational requirements of the Trust, internal and external audit as well as third-parties including the Department of Health, the Care Quality Commission and the Audit Commission.

5.1.2 Establishing a baseline position allows Digital Services to effectively plan, procure, deploy, manage and dispose of assets according to the Trust's strategic requirements, government policy, current best practice guidelines and legislation. This will provide effective service delivery.

5.1.3 IT equipment and information systems are now, and have been for some time, an essential part of the Trust's clinical responsibilities to patients. Failure to effectively manage assets has consequential risks associated with it in potential breaches of data security as well as financial loss.
Procurement of IT Assets
5.2.1 Typically, all IT related assets, including those which come with medical/diagnostic or monitoring equipment, must be procured following prior consultation with Digital Services.

5.2.2 Items that have not been planned for in agreed investment or replacement programmes, must be funded; it is the requesting department's responsibility to secure funding in advance of any orders being placed.
5.2.3 If a non-standard IT asset is requested then a justification for why standard equipment or software is unsuitable for the purpose must be provided.
5.2.4 Other Departments, services and wards are not permitted to specify and procure any IT assets without prior consultation with Digital Services.

5.2.5 If the desired asset is to be networked and/or required to exchange data with IT systems, it is essential that Digital Services be involved as soon as possible in order to provide advice and assistance regarding infrastructure / communication / network implications (including any additional costs associated with implementation).
Asset Register and Inventory (CMDB)

5.3.1 Digital Services are responsible for the procurement and tracking of Information Technology Assets that incur substantial costs. The importance of managing such assets accurately and reliably is essential in supporting financial planning.

5.3.2 IT assets will be deemed as accepted by Digital Services once the asset has been suitably tagged. However this does not negate warranty cover for those assets that have been tagged and fail during the warranty period.

5.3.3 All assets obtained are required to be recorded in the asset management database (in line with local processes) with the following information captured as a minimum for all newly procured assets:
Asset ID tag or other unique identifiable information (serial number of device if it is too small to hold an asset tag)
Type of asset (hardware/software/infrastructure)
Asset classification
Serial number
Procurement date
Procurement Order Number
End of warranty date
Replacement date
Asset original value
Type of warranty
Manufacturer
Model
Originating supplier
SLA rating
Asset charge centre
Site name
Asset physical location (Site/Building/Floor/Room ID/Sub-location)
Client ID (assignment number of asset keeper)
Name of client (asset keeper)
Client telephone number
Email address
Client SLA
Client charge centre
Site name
Asset Tags
5.4.1 All IT assets are required to be tagged with an identifiable label or etching (subject to size of device) that indicates the following:
The NHS logo (where a label is used)
Property is owned by the respective Trust site (or words to that effect depending on the size of the device)
Unique number (unique identifier in the asset management database)
Barcode
Security mechanism (e.g. hologram etc.)

5.4.2 If the IT Asset is a security device and should such identification compromise the effectiveness of the device, the asset should be recorded in the asset management database by unique serial number and not tagged. This should only be used as a last resort and where other risk factors take precedence over the information security or financial risk.
5.4.3 Where this issue requires clarification the decision of the Head of IT or above will override this requirement.
5.4.4 Should the asset tag be defaced at any time in its lifecycle, it should be reported immediately to the IT Service Desk to be repaired / replaced with a new asset tag.
Deployment of Assets
5.5.1 Once tagged, registered, checked and configured (where required) the item will be ready to be deployed.

5.5.2 Equipment will be installed under the overall direction and initial training of a member of the Digital Services team. Once completed, the assigned IT asset keeper will be required to sign to acknowledge receipt of a working installation and formally take responsibility for it.
Acceptable Use of Assets

5.6.1 IT assets will only be used for the purposes of undertaking job functions and any personal usage must be kept to a bare minimum; see User Access & Acceptable Usage Policy for further information regarding Trust expectations.

5.6.2 The assigned ‘keeper' will maintain the IT asset in good physical condition (subject to acceptable and anticipated wear and tear) and not misuse it for use where the Trust's reputation might be brought into disrepute, suffer financial loss or future litigation.
5.6.3 All software is to be installed with the organisation listed to a standard naming convention of the appropriate organisation/Trust.
5.6.4 Users will be subject to Human Resources disciplinary proceedings should it be found that an IT asset has been misused.
Assignment and Control of Assets

5.7.1 Once assigned, full responsibility of the use of the asset will transfer from Digital Services to the person/role recorded in the asset management database as the asset keeper. The Department undertakes to keep the information up to date in accordance with local processes.

5.7.2 Therefore it is essential that this information is kept up to date and again, the responsibility to do this lies with the originally assigned asset keeper or their substantive Line Manager. If, for operational reasons, the asset is passed to another person Digital Services MUST be informed immediately so that the information on the database can be updated promptly. This may be done via the IT Self-service Portal or telephone call to the IT Service Desk.

5.7.3 If this procedure is not followed the last recorded assignee in the database will retain responsibility, unless they have left the employment of the Trust then their Line Manager will assume the responsibility for the asset since – during the leaving process – the IT asset should have been recalled and returned to Digital Services for redeployment by the manager.
Asset Value

5.8.1 When an asset is procured it will have an intrinsic value and this information should be recorded in the IT CMDB for the purposes of being able to report on the cost distribution of such assets throughout the Trust.

5.8.2 Additionally where a device needs to be replaced, a comparative replacement cost will be required in order to see the financial cost to the Trust. If the asset is replaced due to loss or misplacement and is not subsequently found, the department budget will be recharged with the cost of the replacement.
Removal of Assets from Trust premises and Offsite Security
5.9.1 Unless an asset is obviously a portable device (e.g. laptops, smartphones, mobile phone etc.) then, by default, the device should remain in the location where it has been deployed.

5.9.2 Any requirement to move the device (e.g. due to office move etc.) should be notified to the Service Desk who will arrange for the device to be relocated. This will also ensure that the IT CMDB is updated with the new location and owner if applicable. Under no circumstances are staff permitted to move equipment themselves.
5.9.3 If this process is not followed, the possibility of an audit failure could occur and if systemic procedural failure continues Human Resources disciplinary policies may be initiated.

5.9.4 If an authorised portable device is removed from Trust premises, then the assigned user is entirely responsible for providing adequate protection from risk of theft. All portable devices are encrypted by default to comply with Information Governance best practice. However under no circumstances are assets to be left unattended (e.g. in a car boot) or be left in situations that increase the likelihood of theft.

5.9.5 Stolen or lost IT assets due to neglectful behaviour or non-adherence to this policy will be risk assessed for consequential financial loss to the Trust and potential Information Security breach and will be dealt with on a case by case basis under the control of Head of Digital Services and/or Head of Information Governance. Where a user's actions are found, after investigation, to have increased the likelihood of such  theft  this may  invoke  Human  Resources  disciplinary  policies.   The  asset keeper may also be liable for the financial implications and required to reimburse the Trust for such losses that they are responsible for should an investigation find that the loss could have been avoided; reimbursement may be via an individual's insurance policy, home or car, as applicable.
5.9.6 IT asset keepers should bestow the same duty of care on equipment provided to them as they would should their own the property.
Loss or theft of devices
5.10.1 Loss or Theft of any Trust asset, regardless of whether it contains Person Identifiable Information (PII) or other sensitive information, must be reported as soon as possible.
5.10.2 Where a Trust device is lost, mislaid or stolen, the following steps should be taken:

If the device is lost or mislaid, the user must capture this on the Trust incident management system and inform the IT Service Desk immediately, or site office if out of hours, regarding the circumstances.
If a device is stolen from Trust premises, staff must firstly contact the Trust Security Team so they can contact the police and report the device as stolen, and then the IT Service desk.

If a device is stolen whilst off Trust premises, the member of staff must contact the police immediately and report the device as stolen, they should then contact the Trust Security Team and then the IT Service desk providing the police crime reference number.

When calling the IT Service Desk users must inform the call handler if there was any personal/patient identifiable data located on the device. They should also state if it was password protected in order to determine whether the risk of accessing the device and its contents is reportable as a Serious Incident internally and to the ICO.
If the device is subsequently found, the IT Service Desk must be informed immediately.
The loss, misplacement or theft of a portable device does not automatically warrant a replacement being issued. A decision to replace a portable device will be made on a case-by-case basis.

5.10.3 Where the capability exists, a device will be wiped remotely without recourse. When the Trust receives notification of a lost or stolen device, whether Trust or personally owned, it will be wiped of all information. Where this is a personal device, the user will have agreed to this dispensation when access to email and calendar services was authorised.
Asset Lifecycle and Subsequent Replacement
5.11.1 Each asset will have a lifecycle regarding equipment replacement/refresh according to Trust process in force at the time.

5.11.2 Adequate budgets must be available to maintain and replace IT assets to ensure they are fit for purpose, and do not compromise the resilience and security of the Trust IT Enterprise architecture.
Asset Depreciation
5.12.1  IT assets will be depreciated at the rate that is set and varied by the Finance Department from time to time dependant on lifecycle and financial planning policies.
Personally Owned Devices
5.13.1 The Trust supports the use of personal devices in the work place in-line with the Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) Policy; please refer to this policy for further information.
5.13.2 It must be stressed that personally owned devices are not, in any way, the responsibility of the Trust in terms of upgrades or replacement in the event of device failure, loss or theft.
Asset Disposal

5.14.1 IT Assets may only be disposed of when they have reached the end of their useful life, have been superseded by other technologies or have been damaged beyond useful/financially viable repair and the necessary paperwork has been completed and duly authorised.

5.14.2 At this point the asset should be updated on the IT Asset database and disposed of under any currently enforced legal obligations and guidelines. All drives must be rendered inert, i.e. degaussed or destroyed, prior to storing to await disposal.
5.14.3 The disposal of assets should be undertaken in accordance with local processes and National guidance from NHS Digital and WEEE regulations.

5.14.4 Third party suppliers may be contracted to support the secure disposal of IT. Upon completion of the secure disposal of assets suppliers will be required to provide evidence and certification of compliance.
Obligations of staff and line managers on employment termination

5.15.1 It is the users' responsibility to return all Trust equipment, including smartcards and ID  badges,  prior  to  leaving  the  Trust's  employment.  The  line  manager  is responsible for collecting these and returning them to the IT service desk

5.15.2 If the circumstances are summary dismissal the Service Desk must be informed immediately so that assets can be retrieved quickly and system access can be rescinded. Failure to notify Digital Services immediately places PII and PID at risk which will be notified to the Associate Director of Corporate Governance at the earliest opportunity for investigation.
5.15.3 Should employees leave without returning all IT assets, the Trust reserves the right to pursue individuals for the cost of replacement devices.
Training Requirements
Staff are required to complete IG training as part of their annual mandatory training obligations.
Between annual training requirements staff are to ensure that they keep up to date regarding IT or Cyber security update emails and messages published in staff circulars.
6.2.1  If there are any concerns regarding the content or implication of this policy they should be directed to the IT Service Desk.
Monitoring & Audit
